title: Time vs Tip
question_text:
Do customers who shop for a longer time in a store spend more money?
Charlotte, an AP Statistics student who worked at the mall, decided to investigate this question. Over the course of the next few months, she obtained a random sample of receipts, which included the length of time (in minutes) the shopper spent at the mall and the total amount the shopper spent (in dollars). Here is regression output for the data Charlotte collected:
Based on this output, what is the correct value for the $t$ test statistic for determining whether those who stay longer spend more?
tables:
Tip (dollars) versus Time (minutes)
PredictorCoefSE Coef$T$$ P$
Constant$4.535$$1.657$$2.74$$0.021$
Time$0.03013$$0.02448$$0.247$
$S = 1.77931$R-sq = $13.2$%R-sq (adj) = $4.5$%
solution:
Solution

When a computer printout is given after regression is performed, the t test statistic can be found in the second row, under the column header T. This value was intentionally not given here. To calculuate the t test statistic for inference on the slope of a linear relationship, use the formula

$$t = \dfrac{\text{ b } }{\text {SE}_{b}}$$

Here:

$$t = \dfrac{\text{ b } }{\text {SE}_{b}} = \dfrac{0.03013}{0.02448} = 1.23$$

So, Choice 'A' is correct.

Explanation of Distractors

Choice ‘B’ is incorrect: From the printout, this number can be found in the first row, under the column header T. This is the value of the test statistic if inference was being done on the y-intercept of the population regression line, rather than on the slope of the population regression line.

Choice ‘C’ is incorrect: This value is the correct value of the P-value of the test being conducted here.

Choice ‘D’ is incorrect: This value is the P-value for a significance test if inference was being done on the y-intercept of the population regression line, rather than on the slope of the population regression line.

Choice ‘E’ is incorrect: This value is the reciprocal of the correct value of the t test statistic.
